name: spodumene production | spodumene | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/25106/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of milled spodumene in Australia, which is the leading producer of spodumene, with 1,706,618 ton/yr in 2017 (USGS, 2017). Many data come from the dataset "spodumene production [RER]" available in ecoinvent database version 2 and based on the report by Hischier et al. (2007). Modifications to it have been made to reflect the properties of spodumene mined in Australia. Indeed, the amount of the exchange "Spodumene, in ground" have been recalculated based on the lithium content in raw and concentrated ores from Stamp et al. (2012), from the mining site of Talison, Australia. The exchanges "Gangue, in ground" and "non-sulfidic tailing, off-site" have been added for the sake of mass balance. ;References:;USGS, 2017. Minerals Yearbook - Lithium.;Hischier et al., 2007. Life Cycle Inventories of Packaging and Graphical Paper. Fianl report ecoinvent data v.2.0.11. Dübendorf, CH, Swiss Centre for LCI, Empa.;Stamp, A., Lang, D. J., & Wäger, P. A. (2012). Environmental impacts of a transition toward e-mobility: the present and future role of lithium carbonate production. Journal of Cleaner Production, 23(1), 104-112. 

The activity starts from spodumene in the ground.

This activites ends with the production of 1 kg of spodumene. The dataset includes the input of raw materials, machineries, energy consumption, emissions to air, and infrastructure of the site.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is from 2000 to 2012 (date of the publication including information on Lithium content)
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The amount of spodumene in ground and consequently the tailing amount is based on information about the lithium content in raw and concentrated ores from Stamp et al. (2012), from the mining site of Talison, Australia;Reference: ;Stamp, A., Lang, D. J., & Wäger, P. A. (2012). Environmental impacts of a transition toward e-mobility: the present and future role of lithium carbonate production. Journal of Cleaner Production, 23(1), 104-112.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Technology for iron mining, crushing and milling for limestone production are assumed as a first approximation.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Most data are extrapolated from the report by Hischier et al. 2007 (see published source).
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Approximation with data from literature. Amounts are mostly taken from the report by Hischier et al. 2007 (see published source). The amount of spodumene in ground and consequently the tailing amount is based on information about the lithium content in raw and concentrated ores from Stamp et al. (2012), from the mining site of Talison, Australia.

Reference:
Stamp, A., Lang, D. J., & Wäger, P. A. (2012). Environmental impacts of a transition toward e-mobility: the present and future role of lithium carbonate production. Journal of Cleaner Production, 23(1), 104-112.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Spodumene is one of the minerals that are exploited for lithium extraction. The lithium oxide content is from less than 1% up to more than 5%. Most lithium compounds and minerals are used in the ceramics, glass and primary aluminium industry. The four most important lithium minerals are amblygonite, spodumene, petalite, and lepidolite. Thereof spodumene and petalite are used directly in the form of ores or concentrates, especially in the glass industry.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value based on lithium content in pure spodumene in ground (LiAl(SiO3)2), i.e. 3.49% according to Stamp et al. 2012. Molecular weights: Li = 6.94 g/mol; Al = 26.98 g/mol; Si = 28.085 g/mol; O = 16 g/mol

Reference:
Stamp, A., Lang, D. J., & Wäger, P. A. (2012). Environmental impacts of a transition toward e-mobility: the present and future role of lithium carbonate production. Journal of Cleaner Production, 23(1), 104-112.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value based on lithium content in pure spodumene in ground (LiAl(SiO3)2) for which a recovery rate of 95% is assumed, and the li content in extracted ores (1.86% according to Stamp et al. 2012). Molecular weights: Li = 6.94 g/mol; Al = 26.98 g/mol; Si = 28.085 g/mol; O = 16 g/mol

Reference:
Stamp, A., Lang, D. J., & Wäger, P. A. (2012). Environmental impacts of a transition toward e-mobility: the present and future role of lithium carbonate production. Journal of Cleaner Production, 23(1), 104-112.
